ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The meaning of language through logical models, how to evaluate truth-conditionals, predicate logic, lambda calculus
I had no background in semantics before this course, so I developed a strong, basic understanding of the subfield of linguistics.
I learned about formal logic, semantics, and a little bit about pragmatics
I developed an interest in the way day to day conversations work. I know have insight on the relation between what people say and what they mean.
This course helped me gain an understanding of formal semantics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course does well on building off of what was taught in the previous class.

I really liked the structure of assessments in this course. The biweekly problem sets accurately represented the material covered in the previous two weeks, and the final problem set felt challenging but fair. Professor Dayal is a great lecturer, offers a lot of opportunities for extra help, and makes the class really engaging, even for newcomers to semantics.

The only weakness might be the length and difficulty level of some assigned readings. For students with a background in linguistics, they might be decipherable, but other students might struggle more. Because of the amount of reading for some weeks, I had to cut corners and therefore couldn't be as prepared when starting a new unit. A potential solution could be breaking the reading into sections, so students would know which parts should be done before which lecture.

This is a great class for Linguistics majors. Professor Dayal is engaging ro have in class and the material is manageable and interesting. That said, this course can be quite challenging for non-majors.

This course provided a big challenge and was suited for people who have already taken a linguistics course. As someone whose first experience it was in the field, I like the topics but think I should have been more prepared.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would only recommend it to people who are majoring in linguistics.

I really think you must be a linguistics major to take this class. If you are not, it will be difficult to break out of the B/B+ range. The material is very dry, and I think most people are not suited to it. Prof. Dayal is the best person to teach this  she is very forgiving and patient   but this is not the class to take if you are looking for a QR credit.
I would definitely recommend this course, even just for Professor Dayal. It is also a good way to explore another area of linguistics.
Yes, but mostly to linguistics people
I would recommend this course to everyone based on the way it changed my worldview. I do suggest that people interested understand the challenge ahead or take an easier linguistics course first.
Yes. Anyone interested in learning more about how scholars have conceived of meaning and what semantics is would find this course engaging and worthwhile.
